steps.text: {{farmer.name}} flags you down, glancing nervously toward the fields. "You look capable. I need someone to check on something for me. My scarecrow—it's been moving at night. I've seen it from the window, standing in different spots come morning. I'm too old to be losing my mind, but I'm also too old to go out there alone."
{{farmer.name}} grips your arm. "Thank you. It's out in the far field—you can't miss it. Just... be careful. Whatever's happening out there, it isn't natural."
steps.log: Agreed to investigate {{farmer.name}}'s moving scarecrow

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} looks up hopefully. "Did you find anything?" {{farmer.He}} sees your empty hands and sighs. "The far field. The scarecrow's out there. Please—I need to know what's happening."
{{farmer.name}} straightens when {{farmer.he}} sees you. "You've been to the field. I can see it in your face. What did you find?"
options: I need to look into this more

steps.text: You describe what you encountered. {{farmer.name}} listens intently, {{farmer.his}} weathered face cycling through fear, confusion, and resolve.
options: What do you think we should do?::farmer_opinion

steps.text: "A poacher? Using my scarecrow to spook me off my own land?" {{farmer.name}}'s jaw tightens. "I want {{farmer.him}} caught. The Church won't care about some trespasser—they'll say I'm imagining things. But you found proof. Confront the wretch, or I will."
steps.log: {{farmer.name}} wants to confront the poacher directly

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} is quiet for a long moment. "A spirit? Protecting my fields?" {{farmer.He}} looks toward the field, expression softening. "My grandfather always said this land was blessed. If something's watching over it... the Church will want it destroyed. They always do. But if it means no harm—maybe we should leave it be."
steps.log: {{farmer.name}} wants to leave the protective spirit alone

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s face goes pale. "Something... dark? Keeping worse things away?" {{farmer.He}} shudders. "I don't care what it's holding back. I want it gone. Destroyed. The Church will want to capture it, study it—but I won't have that thing lurking in my fields another night. Kill it."
steps.log: {{farmer.name}} wants the dark entity destroyed

steps.text: The scarecrow stands at the field's center, arms outstretched, burlap head tilted slightly. In daylight it looks ordinary enough—straw stuffing, old clothes, a painted face faded by seasons. But something feels wrong. The crows give it wider berth than they should.
You settle into the tall grass and wait. As the sun lowers, you see it—movement. Not the scarecrow itself, but something at its base.
steps.log: Successfully observed the scarecrow from hiding

steps.text: A figure emerges from a covered pit beneath the scarecrow's post—a lean man with a bow and game bag. He adjusts the scarecrow's position, scattering feed to draw birds for tomorrow's hunt. A poacher, using the "haunted" scarecrow to keep {{farmer.name}} away from his hunting ground.

As dusk settles, a faint luminescence gathers around the scarecrow. The burlap face turns—not mechanically, but smoothly, like something alive. A presence radiates from it: watchful, patient, protective. It's guarding these fields. It has been for a very long time.

As darkness falls, the scarecrow's shadow lengthens impossibly. Something within it stirs—not light, but an absence of it. You feel it notice you, feel its attention like cold fingers on your spine. It's holding something back. And it knows you're watching.
Your foot snaps a dry stalk. The sound carries across the quiet field.

You hear scrambling from near the scarecrow—someone bolting through the far wheat. By the time you reach the spot, they're gone. Tracks in the dirt, a dropped snare, a hastily covered pit. Someone was here. A poacher, maybe. But they've fled.
steps.log: Spooked the intruder—they escaped before you could identify them

steps.text: The scarecrow's head turns toward the sound. For a moment, you swear you see a faint glow behind its painted eyes—then nothing. Whatever presence was here has withdrawn, wary of your clumsy approach. You've confirmed something unnatural is present, but learned little else.
steps.log: Alerted the presence—it withdrew before revealing itself

steps.text: The shadows around the scarecrow surge toward you. Cold washes over your body, and for a terrible moment you can't breathe. Then it releases you—a warning. You stumble back, gasping. Something dark inhabits that scarecrow, and it doesn't want to be watched.
steps.log: Encountered something dark in the field—barely escaped

steps.text: You stride toward the scarecrow, ready for whatever comes. Your boldness is rewarded—or punished—with an answer.
steps.log: Confronted the scarecrow directly

steps.text: A man scrambles out from a covered pit at the scarecrow's base, bow in hand, eyes wild. "Wait! Wait—don't turn me in." He's a poacher, using the scarecrow legend to keep the farmer away from prime hunting ground. He looks desperate enough to deal.
options: Get out of here and don't come back::release_poacher

steps.text: As you approach, the air grows warm. The scarecrow doesn't move, but you feel a presence settle around you like a gentle hand on your shoulder. Images flicker through your mind: crops flourishing, storms diverted, pests driven away. A guardian. It's been protecting this farm for generations.

The shadows coalesce, and something speaks—not in words, but in pressure behind your eyes. It shows you what it holds back: blighted things from the forest's edge, hungry spirits, rot that would consume the crops. It is dark, yes. But it stands between this farm and something worse.
options: I don't make deals with shadows::dark_refuse

steps.text: You approach the scarecrow with purpose, but what waits there is ready for you.

A figure bursts from hiding and barrels past you before you can react—a lean man with a hunter's bag. He's gone into the wheat before you can give chase. Tracks suggest a poacher using this spot, but he won't be back while you're watching.
steps.log: A poacher escaped—he'll likely return when things quiet down

steps.text: The presence withdraws as you approach, startled by your aggressive energy. The scarecrow stands lifeless, ordinary. Whatever spirit inhabited it has retreated, unwilling to engage with someone who came looking for a fight. You've confirmed something was here, but it won't show itself to you now.
steps.log: The spirit retreated—your approach was too aggressive

steps.text: The shadows strike before you can react. Cold tears through you—not physical pain, but something deeper, a wound to your spirit. You stagger back, barely keeping your feet. The darkness recedes, satisfied with its warning. You're alive, but shaken. This thing is dangerous.
steps.log: The dark entity attacked—escaped with injuries

steps.text: You speak the words of blessing as you approach. Light gathers around you, faint but unmistakable. The scarecrow's painted eyes seem to track you—and whatever dwells within responds to the sacred power you carry.
steps.log: Used blessing to safely approach the scarecrow

steps.text: The spirit emerges without fear, recognizing the blessing's light. Images flow freely: generations of protection, quiet vigils through storms and blights. It bows to you—or as much as a bound spirit can bow. It will answer your questions. It means no harm.
options: You've served well, but it's time to rest::spirit_release

steps.text: The darkness recoils from your blessing, hissing like water on hot iron. But it doesn't flee—it can't. It's bound here, holding back something worse. In the light of your blessing, you see what it guards against: shapes at the forest's edge, hungry and patient. The dark thing looks at you with something like desperate pride.
options: The Church can deal with whatever you're holding back::dark_refuse

steps.text: "Please," he begs. "I've got a family. The lord's forests are off-limits, but a man has to eat. I'll stop—I swear it. Just don't drag me to the guards."

The poacher's eyes narrow, calculating. Then he reaches into his bag and pulls out a wrapped bundle—fresh game, cleanly dressed. "Take it. And forget you saw me." He's gone before you can change your mind.
steps.log: Accepted a bribe from the poacher to keep quiet

steps.text: The poacher doesn't wait for you to reconsider. He grabs his gear and vanishes into the wheat, leaving only trampled stalks. {{farmer.name}} won't be troubled again—probably.
steps.log: Let the poacher go with a warning

steps.text: You march the poacher back toward the farmhouse. He doesn't resist, but his eyes keep darting to the tree line, calculating whether he could make a run for it.
You step out of hiding, hands open and empty. The luminescence pulses once—acknowledgment. The spirit regards you without hostility, curious about this mortal who came to watch rather than attack.

The warmth of the spirit's presence wraps around you. It cannot speak in words, but you understand: it was bound here long ago, charged with protecting these fields. It has kept its vigil faithfully. It does not wish to leave, but it will accept judgment if it must.
steps.log: Made peaceful contact with the protective spirit

steps.text: With your blessing, you speak words of release. The spirit shudders, then brightens—gratitude and relief washing over you. It rises from the scarecrow like morning mist, hovering for a moment, then dissipates into the fading light. The fields feel emptier. But the spirit is free.
steps.log: Released the spirit from its binding

steps.text: You force yourself to remain still as the darkness regards you. It doesn't attack—not yet. It's waiting to see what you'll do.

The darkness shows you: it needs nothing from humans. It was placed here to hold back what lurks at the forest's edge. It will continue until destroyed or released—but if released, what it guards against will come. It offers no deal, only truth.
steps.log: Learned the dark entity guards against something worse

steps.text: You back away from the scarecrow, refusing to engage further. The shadows settle, neither advancing nor retreating. Whatever this thing is, it's bound here. It won't chase you. But it won't leave, either.
steps.log: Refused to bargain with the dark entity

steps.text: The priest listens to your tale with polite skepticism. "A poacher? Using fear of spirits to hunt in peace?" He chuckles. "Clever, in a base sort of way. But this is a matter for the farmer, not the Church. The old man sees ghosts where there are only men. Our gods protect us from true evil—a poacher is merely a nuisance."
options: The farmer deserves to know he's not mad::church_prankster_push

steps.text: The priest waves a hand dismissively. "Then tell him. But don't expect us to hunt down every trespasser in the fields. We have genuine spiritual matters to attend to." He turns back to his candles. The Church won't help with this.
steps.log: The Church dismissed the poacher as not their concern

steps.text: The priest's expression grows grave as you describe the spirit. "A bound guardian? Protecting the fields?" He shakes his head slowly. "It matters not whether its intentions are good. Such things do not belong in our world. The spirit must be released—sent to its proper rest. This is not cruelty; it is mercy. Bring me to it, and I will perform the rites."
options: What if the farmer wants it to stay?::church_spirit_argue
I need to think about this

steps.text: "The farmer's wishes are irrelevant to the natural order," the priest says firmly. "A spirit bound to the mortal world suffers, even if it doesn't know it. And such bindings can... sour, over time. What protects today may possess tomorrow. We must act while the creature remains benevolent."
options: Very well. I'll take you there::church_destroy_spirit
I need to think about this
steps.log: The Church insists the spirit must be released

steps.text: The priest accompanies you to the field. The spirit emerges at his approach—and the priest speaks words of dismissal, holy light streaming from his hands. The spirit doesn't resist. It bows once toward the farmhouse, then fades into nothing. "It is done," the priest says. "The farmer's fields are cleansed. And you—" he touches your forehead, "—have earned the Church's blessing."
steps.log: Helped the Church destroy the protective spirit—received blessing

steps.text: The priest's face goes pale as you describe the dark presence. "This is... troubling. Such entities do not appear without cause. If it truly holds something worse at bay..." He strokes his chin. "We must capture it. Contain it. Study what it guards against before we risk destroying the barrier. Can you lure it from its binding? We have a sanctified vessel that could hold it."
options: The farmer wants it destroyed outright::church_dark_argue
I need to think about this

steps.text: "Destroyed?" The priest's eyes widen. "Without knowing what it guards against? That farmer would doom his own fields—perhaps the whole town—out of fear. No. We capture it first, learn what we face, then act with wisdom rather than panic. This is not negotiable."
options: Very well. I'll help capture it::church_capture_dark
I need to think about this
steps.log: The Church insists on capturing the dark entity

steps.text: The priest gives you a sanctified vessel—a small iron box etched with holy symbols. At the field, you present it to the darkness. It resists at first, but the priest's chanting weakens its grip on the scarecrow. With a sound like tearing cloth, the shadow pours into the box. The priest seals it with trembling hands. "This will be secured in the Church vaults. You've done holy work today." He blesses you before departing with his prize.
steps.log: Helped the Church capture the dark entity—received blessing

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} looks at you expectantly. "Well? What did you find out there?"
options: Just your imagination. The scarecrow's fine.::farmhouse_prankster_lie
There was a poacher. I dealt with it.::farmhouse_prankster_vague

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s face falls. "My imagination? But I saw—" {{farmer.He}} trails off, doubt creeping in. "Maybe you're right. Maybe I'm just getting old." The farmer turns away, shoulders slumped. You leave with game meat in your pack and guilt in your gut.
steps.log: Lied to {{farmer.name}} about the poacher

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s eyes widen. "A poacher! I knew something was wrong." {{farmer.He}} grips your arm. "You've done me a great service. The fields are safe now?" You nod, and the farmer's relief is palpable. "Thank you. If you ever need anything, you come to me."
steps.log: Told {{farmer.name}} about the poacher—earned the farmer's gratitude

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} stares at the poacher with cold fury. "You. You've been using my fields, scaring me in my own home." The poacher hangs his head. {{farmer.name}} turns to you. "I'll deal with this wretch. Take this for your trouble—" {{farmer.he}} presses a silver coin into your hand. "You've given an old {{farmer.him}} peace of mind."
steps.log: Delivered the poacher to {{farmer.name}}—received silver

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} looks at you expectantly. "Did you find what's been moving my scarecrow?"
options: A poacher. I ran him off—he won't be back.::farmhouse_poacher_released_end

steps.text: "A poacher!" {{farmer.name}} slaps {{farmer.his}} knee. "I knew I wasn't seeing things. Well, good riddance to him. Thank you for putting my mind at ease. If you ever need help, you know where to find me."
steps.log: Reported the poacher to {{farmer.name}}—earned gratitude

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} is waiting anxiously. "What did you find?"
options: A spirit—protecting your fields. It means no harm.::farmhouse_spirit_report

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s eyes go wide. "A spirit? A real one?" {{farmer.He}} sits heavily on a stool. "Protecting us. After all these years." A long silence. "The Church will want it gone, won't they? They always do." {{farmer.He}} looks at you. "But if it's keeping my crops safe... can't we just leave it be?"
options: I'll tell the Church it's harmless—they don't need to know::protect_spirit_end
I already released it—it's at peace now::spirit_already_released

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} grabs your hand. "Thank you. Thank you." Tears glisten in {{farmer.his}} eyes. "My grandfather always said there was something watching over this land. Now I know he was right." You leave knowing the Church might disapprove if they ever learned the truth—but the farmer's gratitude is worth something.
steps.log: Agreed to protect the spirit's secret—lost Church's blessing

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s face falls, but {{farmer.he}} nods slowly. "I suppose... I suppose that's the right thing. Just—ask them to be gentle with it? It's only ever helped us."
You leave the farmer to anxious waiting. The spirit's fate now rests with the Church.

{{farmer.name}} blinks. "Released? You mean... gone?" {{farmer.He}} looks toward the field, expression conflicted. "I suppose that's for the best. It served its purpose, and now it can rest." {{farmer.He}} pats your shoulder. "You did right by everyone. Thank you."
steps.log: Told {{farmer.name}} the spirit was released—earned gratitude

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} sees your expression and knows. "It's gone, isn't it? The spirit?" You nod. "The Church." It's not a question. {{farmer.He}} turns away. "I suppose they know best. They always say they do." The farmer's voice is flat. "Thank you for your help. You can go now."
steps.log: {{farmer.name}} learned the spirit was destroyed—disappointed

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} can see the weight on you. "That bad, is it?"
options: Something dark—but it's holding back something worse::farmhouse_dark_report

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} goes pale. "Holding back—? No. No, I don't care what it's guarding against. I want it gone. Destroyed. You hear me?" {{farmer.He}} grips your arm. "The Church will want to study it, capture it, keep it around. But I won't have that shadow on my land another night. End it."
options: The Church might know best here::church_dark_defer
It's already been captured by the Church::dark_already_captured

steps.text: You return to the field at dawn, when shadows are weakest. It takes everything you have—will, steel, and the farmer's desperate prayers at your back—but you drive the darkness out. The scarecrow collapses, just straw and cloth now. {{farmer.name}} weeps with relief. "Thank you. Whatever comes, at least it won't come from inside my fields." The Church won't be pleased when they hear. But the farmer is at peace.
steps.log: Destroyed the dark entity as the farmer wished—lost Church's blessing

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s jaw tightens. "The Church. Of course." {{farmer.He}} turns away. "Do what you must. I'll sleep with a knife under my pillow until it's settled."
options: I'll make sure it's dealt with::church_dark_defer_end

steps.text: You leave the farmer to uneasy waiting. Whatever the Church decides, {{farmer.name}} won't rest easy until that shadow is gone entirely.

"Captured?" {{farmer.name}}'s voice rises. "Not destroyed? They've got that—that thing locked up somewhere, still existing?" {{farmer.He}} shudders. "What if it escapes? What if it—" {{farmer.He}} can't finish. "Go. Just go." The farmer turns away. You've lost {{farmer.his}} trust.
steps.log: {{farmer.name}} learned the dark entity was only captured—lost trust

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} looks at you hopefully. "Any luck?"
options: Someone was there—a poacher, I think—but he escaped::farmhouse_prankster_fled

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} sighs. "At least I'm not mad. A poacher, you say? Well, maybe he'll stay away now that he knows someone's looking." The farmer doesn't seem satisfied, but there's nothing more to be done. For now.
steps.log: Reported the escaped poacher to {{farmer.name}}

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} searches your face. "What did you find?"
options: Something's there—but it withdrew before I could learn more::farmhouse_spirit_inconclusive

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} frowns. "Something, but you don't know what?" {{farmer.He}} looks toward the field. "I suppose that's something. At least I know I'm not imagining it." The mystery remains unsolved, but the farmer seems marginally comforted.
steps.log: Reported inconclusive findings to {{farmer.name}}

steps.text: {{farmer.name}} sees you limping back and rushes over. "What happened? Are you hurt?"
options: Something dark. It attacked me. I barely got away.::farmhouse_dark_failed

steps.text: {{farmer.name}}'s face goes white. "Dark? Attack—" {{farmer.He}} grabs your arm. "Stay here. Rest. I'll... I'll figure something out." The farmer helps you to a chair, clearly terrified but trying to be brave. The scarecrow still stands in the field. The problem remains.
steps.log: Reported attack by dark entity—quest ended inconclusively

steps.text: The scarecrow stands where you left it. The poacher's covered pit is still visible if you know where to look. He'll return eventually—they always do.
The scarecrow stands motionless in the fading light. You know what dwells within it now—a guardian spirit, old and patient. It's aware of your presence, waiting to see what you'll do.
The scarecrow's shadow seems longer than it should be, even in full daylight. The darkness within knows you've seen it. It waits, neither hostile nor welcoming—just watching.
{{farmer.name}} looks up from {{farmer.his}} work. "Have you dealt with that poacher yet? I meant what I said—if you won't confront him, I will. I'm not as feeble as I look."

{{farmer.name}} watches you from the porch. "Still thinking on what to do about our... visitor?" {{farmer.He}} glances toward the field. "Take your time. It's waited this long. But don't let the Church make the decision for us, eh?"

{{farmer.name}} hasn't slept—you can see it in {{farmer.his}} eyes. "That thing's still out there. Have you figured out what to do about it? I won't rest easy until it's gone. Gone, you hear? Not captured, not contained. Gone."

{{farmer.name}} is sitting on the porch, cleaning a brace of rabbits. Fresh game. {{farmer.He}} looks up at you with a mixture of satisfaction and disappointment. "Took care of it myself. Found the wretch's pit, waited for him with my pitchfork. He won't be back." {{farmer.He}} tosses a silver coin at your feet. "For your trouble. You did find him, even if you couldn't be bothered to finish the job."
You pocket the coin. {{farmer.name}} has already turned back to {{farmer.his}} rabbits, clearly done with the conversation. Not the outcome you'd hoped for, but at least the problem is solved.
steps.log: {{farmer.name}} dealt with the poacher personally—received token payment

steps.text: The priest listens to your tale with polite skepticism. "A poacher? Using fear of spirits to hunt in peace?" He chuckles. "Clever, in a base sort of way. But this is a matter for the farmer, not the Church. The old {{farmer.name}} sees ghosts where there are only men. Our gods protect us from true evil—a poacher is merely a nuisance."
options: The farmer deserves to know he's not mad::church_prankster_push

steps.text: The scarecrow stands alone in the field, just straw and old clothes. The poacher's pit has been filled in with fresh dirt—someone's boot prints circle the area. {{farmer.name}}'s work, by the look of it. The problem has been handled, though not by you.
